chapter.title: DHIS2 in the Autonomous Region of Kurdistan

para.emphasis: For the thousands of refugees stranded in camps across the war-torn Autonomous Region of Iraqi Kurdistan, getting access to regular health care hasn’t always been straightforward.

section.para: In June 2015, a DHIS2 Health Information System was set up to assist the Kurdish health authorities in collecting population data and improving the access and quality of public health care.

A KRG-DHIS2 pilot project led by the University of Tor Vergata, Rome, and realized by I-PRO and Euresist was deployed across a set of pilot health centers and hospitals in the Kurdish directorates of Erbil, Duhok and Slemani.

With 60 registered users spread across 30 health centers, 700 Kurdish medical professionals can now follow a staggering 150,000 health events! Indeed, just 16 months into the pilot project, there are now 7 primary/family health centers, 9 hospitals, and 14 general health centers, 10 health centers in rural areas or small towns/villages, and 20 health centers in major towns.

100,000 cases have been imported via periodic uploads from existing and running databases, and 50,000 cases have been recorded by DHIS2 users. This great progress is enabling health professionals to gather statistics for disease diagnoses, hospital discharges, registrations of births, deaths and immunizations.

section.title: Key implementation challenges
section.para: With a small time frame to get a DHIS2 epidemiological surveillance pilot project implemented and deployed in the whole Kurdish region of Iraq, many challenges lay ahead for the teams involved.

Racing against the clock. The first challenge lay in building a solution that would work in a short time; one that would satisfy the basic needs of the regional health system in collecting data. A subset of the regional health centers, approximately 30 establishments, made up of rural and urban centers, family health centers, hospitals, hospital colleges and general health centers were involved in testing the system.

Pulling in data from other systems. Another challenge lay in importing existing data already used in hospitals in to DHIS2; making it possible to enter data from mobile devices; preparing reports equal to those requested from the health centers by the health directorates; and building a DHIS2 system to be used by people without a background in health.

Testing using a small, live version of DHIS2. The testing phase was centered around two areas: data sets with aggregate data entry, and programs with disaggregate event data capture. After analyzing the data reports produced by the tests, the project managers decided to use programs without registration using the Event Capture app.

Capturing data with the Event Capture app. In this region of Iraq, people do not have identification numbers. It's therefore almost impossible to follow patients' visits to different health centers. Bearing this in mind, we decided to build a system to record basic health events such as births, deaths, immunizations, disease diagnoses and hospital discharges using the Event Capture app. Using this app, you can import existing data from hospital databases while adhering to the same data structure, which is extremely helpful. Physicians or other health technicians are able to enter data in real-time while a visitation is taking place, without having to complete further data aggregation operations.

Hosting. Without the means to implement a dedicated server, we chose to use an outsourced hosting solution through a recommended company called BAO Systems. With this solution we will be able to scale up our DHIS2 instance in the future.

Translating the UI into Kurdish-Sorani. With the help of the DHIS2 community and its developers and translation team, we were able to translate the DHIS2 user interface into Kurdish-Sorani, a language which is spoken by 6 million people in Iraq.

section.title: What's ahead?
section.para: Creating national health numbers for all citizens Our main focus for the upcoming years is to introduce a national health identity (HNID) for each citizen accessing health services. Once this is in place, we plan to integrate the HNID into the Kurdish DHIS2 platform. Furthermore, we plan to involve at least 300 health centers in our KRG-DHIS2 platform. Finally, our aim is to grow and to extend DHIS2 to other areas besides health.
